<div class="floatright"><a href="/wiki/File:Doctor_Who_logo_2012.svg" title="File:Doctor Who logo 2012.svg">250px</a></div>
<p><i><a href="/wiki/Doctor_Who" title="Doctor Who">Doctor Who</a></i> is a British <a href="/wiki/Science_fiction_on_television" title="Science fiction on television">science fiction television</a> programme produced by the <a href="/w/index.php?title=BBC&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="BBC (page does not exist)">BBC</a>. As of 25 December 2013, 800 individual episodes, including one television movie of <i>Doctor Who</i>, have been aired, encompassing 241 stories. Additionally, four charity specials and two animated serials have also been aired. The show's high episode count resulted in <i>Doctor Who</i> holding the <a href="/w/index.php?title=World_record&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="World record (page does not exist)">world record</a> for the highest number of episodes for a science-fiction programme.<sup id="cite_ref-record_1-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-record-1">[1]</a></sup> For comparison, the <a href="/wiki/Guinness_World_Record" title="Guinness World Record" class="mw-redirect">Guinness World Record</a> holder for the highest number of consecutive episodes, <i><a href="/wiki/Smallville" title="Smallville">Smallville</a></i>,<sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2">[2]</a></sup> aired 218 episodes.
</p><p><i>Doctor Who</i> ceased airing in 1989 and <a href="/wiki/History_of_Doctor_Who#Ninth_Doctor" title="History of Doctor Who">began again in 2005</a>.  Each story in the original series (1963–89) is a multi-episode serial, with two exceptions: the 1965 <a href="/wiki/Cutaway_(filmmaking)" title="Cutaway (filmmaking)">cutaway</a> episode "<a href="/wiki/Mission_to_the_Unknown" title="Mission to the Unknown">Mission to the Unknown</a>" and the 20th anniversary story <i><a href="/wiki/The_Five_Doctors" title="The Five Doctors">The Five Doctors</a></i>. The characters in the column after the serial titles indicate the code used by the production team to designate the serial, where applicable, and are followed either by the titles of the individual episodes where given or by the number of episodes otherwise. Unless otherwise noted, episodes in this period are 25 minutes long. During the early seasons of the programme most serials were linked together and one would usually lead directly into the next. Starting with the 2005 revival, the production team abandoned the traditional serial format for a largely self-contained episodic format with occasional multi-part stories and loose <a href="/w/index.php?title=Story_arcs_in_Doctor_Who&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Story arcs in Doctor Who (page does not exist)">story arcs</a>. Unless otherwise noted, the new episodes are 45 minutes long.
</p><p>Due to the BBC's 1970s <a href="/wiki/Wiping#BBC" title="Wiping">junking</a> policy, 97 episodes from the 1960s are <a href="/wiki/Doctor_Who_missing_episodes" title="Doctor Who missing episodes">missing</a>, with the result that 26  serials are incomplete, although all of these still exist as audio recordings, and some have been reconstructed. In the first two seasons and most of the third, each episode of a serial had an individual title; no serial had an overall on-screen title until <i><a href="/wiki/The_Savages_(Doctor_Who)" title="The Savages (Doctor Who)">The Savages</a></i>. The serial titles given below are the most common title for the serials as a whole, used in sources such as the <i>Doctor Who</i> Reference Guide and the BBC's classic episode guide, and are generally those used for commercial release. The practice of individually titled episodes resurfaced with the show's 2005 revival, when <i>Doctor Who</i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:%27s&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:'s (page does not exist)">Template:'s</a> serial nature was abandoned in favour of an episodic format.
</p><p>The three-digit story numbers are not official designations but are merely to serve as a guide to where the story stands in the overall context of the programme. There is some dispute about, for example, whether to count Season 23's <i><a href="/wiki/The_Trial_of_a_Time_Lord" title="The Trial of a Time Lord">The Trial of a Time Lord</a></i> as one or four serials,<sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3">[3]</a></sup> and whether the uncompleted <i><a href="/wiki/Shada" title="Shada">Shada</a></i> should be included.<sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4">[4]</a></sup> The numbering scheme used here reflects the current internal practice of describing "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Planet_of_the_Dead&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Planet of the Dead (page does not exist)">Planet of the Dead</a>" (2009) as the 200th story, used in the <a href="/wiki/Doctor_Who_Magazine" title="Doctor Who Magazine">official magazine's</a> 407th issue.<sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5">[5]</a></sup> Other sources, such as the <a href="/wiki/DVD_region_code" title="DVD region code">Region 1</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Doctor_Who_DVD_releases&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Doctor Who DVD releases (page does not exist)">DVDs of classic <i>Doctor Who</i> serials</a>, use different numbering schemes which diverge after the 108th story, <i>The Horns of Nimon</i> (1979/80).
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Series_overview">Series overview</span></h2>

<ol class="references">
<li id="cite_note-6"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><a href="#cite_ref-6">↑</a></span> <span class="reference-text">Average viewing figures for the series do not include the audience figures for the Christmas special as they can falsely represent the respective series.</span>
</li>
</ol>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="First_Doctor">First Doctor</span></h2>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/First_Doctor" title="First Doctor">first incarnation</a> of <a href="/wiki/Doctor_(Doctor_Who)" title="Doctor (Doctor Who)">the Doctor</a> was portrayed by <a href="/wiki/William_Hartnell" title="William Hartnell">William Hartnell</a>. During Hartnell's tenure, the Doctor visited a mixture of stories set in the future and in historical events that had no extraterrestrial influence, such as fifteenth century <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mesoamerica&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mesoamerica (page does not exist)">Mesoamerica</a>. In his last story, <i>The Tenth Planet</i>, the Doctor gradually grew weaker to the point of collapsing at the end of the fourth episode, leading to his <a href="/w/index.php?title=Regeneration_(Doctor_Who)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Regeneration (Doctor Who) (page does not exist)">regeneration</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Season_1_.281963.E2.80.9364.29_.7B.7B.23invoke:anchor.7Cmain.7D.7D">Season 1 (1963–64) {{#invoke:anchor|main}}</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
<a href="/wiki/Verity_Lambert" title="Verity Lambert">Verity Lambert</a> was producer with <a href="/wiki/David_Whitaker_(screenwriter)" title="David Whitaker (screenwriter)">David Whitaker</a> serving as script editor.
</p>

<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Season_2_.281964.E2.80.9365.29_.7B.7B.23invoke:anchor.7Cmain.7D.7D">Season 2 (1964–65) {{#invoke:anchor|main}}</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
<a href="/wiki/Dennis_Spooner" title="Dennis Spooner">Dennis Spooner</a> replaced David Whitaker as script editor after <i>The Dalek Invasion of Earth</i>, and edited the remainder of the season apart from <i>The Time Meddler</i>, which was edited by <a href="/wiki/Donald_Tosh" title="Donald Tosh">Donald Tosh</a>.
</p>
<table class="wikitable" style="width:100%; margin-right:0;">

<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Season_3_.281965.E2.80.9366.29_.7B.7B.23invoke:anchor.7Cmain.7D.7D">Season 3 (1965–66) {{#invoke:anchor|main}}</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
<a href="/wiki/John_Wiles" title="John Wiles">John Wiles</a> replaced Verity Lambert as producer after <i>Mission to the Unknown</i>. <a href="/wiki/Innes_Lloyd" title="Innes Lloyd">Innes Lloyd</a>, in turn, replaced Wiles after <i>The Ark</i>. Donald Tosh continued as script editor until <i>The Massacre of St Bartholomew's Eve</i>, which was also script-edited by his replacement, <a href="/wiki/Gerry_Davis_(screenwriter)" title="Gerry Davis (screenwriter)">Gerry Davis</a>. The practice of giving each individual episode a different title was abandoned after <i>The Gunfighters</i>, near the end of the season.
</p>
<table class="wikitable" style="width:100%; margin-right:0;">

</td></tr></table>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Second_Doctor">Second Doctor</span></h2>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Second_Doctor" title="Second Doctor">Second Doctor</a> was portrayed by <a href="/wiki/Patrick_Troughton" title="Patrick Troughton">Patrick Troughton</a>, whose serials were more action-oriented than those of his predecessor. Additionally, after <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Highlanders_(Doctor_Who)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Highlanders (Doctor Who) (page does not exist)">The Highlanders</a></i>, stories moved away from the purely historical ones that featured during William Hartnell's tenure; instead, any historical tales also included a science fiction element. Patrick Troughton retained the role until the last episode of <i>The War Games</i> when members of the Doctor's race, the <a href="/wiki/Time_Lord" title="Time Lord">Time Lords</a>, put him on trial for breaking the laws of time and forced him to regenerate.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Season_4_.281966.E2.80.9367.29_continued">Season 4 (1966–67) continued</span></h3>
<p><a href="/wiki/Peter_Bryant" title="Peter Bryant">Peter Bryant</a> joined as associate producer for <i>The Faceless Ones</i>, and replaced Gerry Davis as script editor for the last four episodes of <i>The Evil of the Daleks</i>.
</p>
<table class="wikitable" style="width:100%; margin-right:0;">

<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Season_5_.281967.E2.80.9368.29_.7B.7B.23invoke:anchor.7Cmain.7D.7D">Season 5 (1967–68) {{#invoke:anchor|main}}</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
<a href="/wiki/Victor_Pemberton" title="Victor Pemberton">Victor Pemberton</a> was script editor for <i>The Tomb of the Cybermen</i>, with Peter Bryant as producer. After this, Bryant resumed the role of script editor, with Innes Lloyd returning as producer, until <i>The Web of Fear</i> when Bryant took over from Lloyd as producer. <a href="/wiki/Derrick_Sherwin" title="Derrick Sherwin">Derrick Sherwin</a> replaced Bryant as script editor at the same time.
</p>

<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Season_6_.281968.E2.80.9369.29_.7B.7B.23invoke:anchor.7Cmain.7D.7D">Season 6 (1968–69) {{#invoke:anchor|main}}</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Terrance_Dicks" title="Terrance Dicks">Terrance Dicks</a> took over from Derrick Sherwin as script editor from <i>The Invasion</i>, with Sherwin resuming the role for <i>The Space Pirates</i>. Derrick Sherwin took over as producer from Peter Bryant for <i>The War Games</i>.
</p>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Third_Doctor">Third Doctor</span></h2>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Third_Doctor" title="Third Doctor">Third Doctor</a> was portrayed by <a href="/wiki/Jon_Pertwee" title="Jon Pertwee">Jon Pertwee</a>. Sentenced to exile on Earth and forcibly regenerated at the end of <i>The War Games</i>, the Doctor spent his time working for <a href="/wiki/UNIT" title="UNIT">UNIT</a>. After <i>The Three Doctors</i>, the Time Lords repealed his exile; however, the Doctor still worked closely with UNIT from time to time. The Third Doctor regenerated into his fourth incarnation as a result of radiation poisoning in the last moments of <i><a href="/wiki/Planet_of_the_Spiders" title="Planet of the Spiders">Planet of the Spiders</a></i>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Season_7_.281970.29">Season 7 (1970)</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
<a href="/wiki/Barry_Letts" title="Barry Letts">Barry Letts</a> took over as producer from Derrick Sherwin after <i><a href="/wiki/Spearhead_from_Space" title="Spearhead from Space">Spearhead from Space</a></i>. From this season onwards the programme was produced in colour. To accommodate the new production methods the number of episodes in a season was cut: season 6 has 44 episodes; season 7 has 25 episodes. The seasons would continue to have between 20 and 26 episodes until season 22.
</p>
<table class="wikitable" style="width:100%; margin-right:0;">

<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Season_8_.281971.29">Season 8 (1971)</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
This season forms a loose arc with the introduction of <a href="/wiki/Master_(Doctor_Who)" title="Master (Doctor Who)">the Master</a>, the villain in each of the season's storylines, and introduces the companion <a href="/wiki/Jo_Grant" title="Jo Grant">Jo Grant</a>.
</p>

<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Season_11_.281973.E2.80.9374.29_.7B.7B.23invoke:anchor.7Cmain.7D.7D">Season 11 (1973–74) {{#invoke:anchor|main}}</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
This season introduces the companion <a href="/wiki/Sarah_Jane_Smith" title="Sarah Jane Smith">Sarah Jane Smith</a>.
</p>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Fourth_Doctor">Fourth Doctor</span></h2>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Fourth_Doctor" title="Fourth Doctor">Fourth Doctor</a> was portrayed by <a href="/wiki/Tom_Baker" title="Tom Baker">Tom Baker</a>. He is, to date, the actor who has played the Doctor on television for the longest time,<sup id="cite_ref-20" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-20">[12]</a></sup> having held the role for seven seasons.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Season_12_.281974.E2.80.9375.29_.7B.7B.23invoke:anchor.7Cmain.7D.7D">Season 12 (1974–75) {{#invoke:anchor|main}}</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
Barry Letts served as producer for <i><a href="/wiki/Robot_(Doctor_Who)" title="Robot (Doctor Who)">Robot</a></i>, after which he was succeeded by <a href="/wiki/Philip_Hinchcliffe" title="Philip Hinchcliffe">Philip Hinchcliffe</a>. <a href="/wiki/Robert_Holmes_(scriptwriter)" title="Robert Holmes (scriptwriter)">Robert Holmes</a> took over from Terrance Dicks as script editor. All serials in this season continue directly one after the other, tracing one single problematic voyage of the TARDIS crew. Despite the continuity, each serial is considered its own standalone story. This season also introduced the character of <a href="/wiki/Harry_Sullivan_(Doctor_Who)" title="Harry Sullivan (Doctor Who)">Harry Sullivan</a> as a companion; this character was intended to undertake action scenes, during the period prior to Tom Baker being cast, when it was unclear how old the actor playing the new Doctor would be.
</p>
<table class="wikitable" style="width:100%; margin-right:0;">

<tr>
<th scope="col" style="width:4%;"> No

<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Season_13_.281975.E2.80.9376.29_.7B.7B.23invoke:anchor.7Cmain.7D.7D">Season 13 (1975–76) {{#invoke:anchor|main}}</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
During this season, Ian Marter (Harry Sullivan) left after <i>Terror of the Zygons</i>, but returned for a guest appearance in <i>The Android Invasion</i>. <i>Terror of the Zygons</i> also saw the last semi-regular appearance of Nicholas Courtney (Brigadier Lethbridge-Stewart) who would not return until Season 20 in <i>Mawdryn Undead</i>.
</p>

<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Season_14_.281976.E2.80.9377.29_.7B.7B.23invoke:anchor.7Cmain.7D.7D">Season 14 (1976–77) {{#invoke:anchor|main}}</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
Elizabeth Sladen (Sarah Jane Smith) left the series this season and was replaced by <a href="/wiki/Louise_Jameson" title="Louise Jameson">Louise Jameson</a> (Leela). The season also saw the first story in which the Doctor did not have a companion, <i>The Deadly Assassin</i>.
</p>

<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Season_15_.281977.E2.80.9378.29_.7B.7B.23invoke:anchor.7Cmain.7D.7D">Season 15 (1977–78) {{#invoke:anchor|main}}</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
<a href="/wiki/Graham_Williams_(television_producer)" title="Graham Williams (television producer)">Graham Williams</a> took over as producer from Philip Hinchcliffe. Robert Holmes was replaced as script editor by <a href="/wiki/Anthony_Read" title="Anthony Read">Anthony Read</a> during <i>The Sun Makers</i>.
</p>

<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Season_16_.281978.E2.80.9379.29_.7B.7B.23invoke:anchor.7Cmain.7D.7D">Season 16 (1978–79) {{#invoke:anchor|main}}</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
<a href="/wiki/Douglas_Adams" title="Douglas Adams">Douglas Adams</a> took over as script editor from Anthony Read for <i><a href="/wiki/The_Armageddon_Factor" title="The Armageddon Factor">The Armageddon Factor</a></i>. Season 16 consists of one long <a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Key_to_Time&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Key to Time (page does not exist)">story arc</a> encompassing six separate, linked stories. This season is referred to by the umbrella title <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Key_to_Time&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Key to Time (page does not exist)">The Key to Time</a></i> and has been released on DVD under this title.
</p>
<table class="wikitable" style="width:100%; margin-right:0;">

<tr>
<th scope="col" style="width:4%;"> No
</th>
<th scope="col" style="width:27%;"> Title
</th>
<th scope="col" style="width:5%;"> Code
</th>
<th scope="col" style="width:20%;"> Episodes
</th>
<th scope="col" style="width:13%;"> Writer
</th>
<th scope="col" style="width:15%;"> Director
</th>

<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Season_18_.281980.E2.80.9381.29_.7B.7B.23invoke:anchor.7Cmain.7D.7D">Season 18 (1980–81) {{#invoke:anchor|main}}</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
<a href="/wiki/John_Nathan-Turner" title="John Nathan-Turner">John Nathan-Turner</a> replaced Graham Williams as producer. Barry Letts returned, as executive producer, for just this season. <a href="/wiki/Christopher_H._Bidmead" title="Christopher H. Bidmead">Christopher H. Bidmead</a> replaced Douglas Adams as script editor. In a return to the format of early seasons, virtually all serials from Seasons 18 through 20 are linked together, often running directly into each other.
</p><p>Season 18 forms a <a href="/w/index.php?title=E-Space_trilogy&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="E-Space trilogy (page does not exist)">loose story arc</a> dealing with the theme of <a href="/wiki/Entropy" title="Entropy">entropy</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/Full_Circle_(Doctor_Who)" title="Full Circle (Doctor Who)">Full Circle</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/State_of_Decay" title="State of Decay">State of Decay</a></i>, and <i><a href="/wiki/Warriors%27_Gate" title="Warriors' Gate">Warriors' Gate</a></i> trace the Doctor's adventures in <a href="/w/index.php?title=E-Space&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="E-Space (page does not exist)">E-Space</a>; they were released in both VHS and DVD boxsets with the umbrella title <i>The E-Space Trilogy</i>.
</p>
<table class="wikitable" style="width:100%; margin-right:0;">

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Fifth_Doctor">Fifth Doctor</span></h2>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Fifth_Doctor" title="Fifth Doctor">Fifth Doctor</a> was portrayed by <a href="/wiki/Peter_Davison" title="Peter Davison">Peter Davison</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Season_19_.281982.29">Season 19 (1982)</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
<a href="/wiki/Antony_Root" title="Antony Root">Antony Root</a> took over from Bidmead as script editor for <i>Four to Doomsday</i> and <i>The Visitation</i>, after which he was replaced by <a href="/wiki/Eric_Saward" title="Eric Saward">Eric Saward</a>. The show moved from its traditional once-weekly Saturday broadcast to being broadcast twice-weekly primarily on Monday and Tuesday, although there were regional variations to the schedule.
</p><p><i>Castrovalva</i>, together with the previous two serials, <i>The Keeper of Traken</i> and <i>Logopolis</i>, form a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Story_arcs_in_Doctor_Who&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Story arcs in Doctor Who (page does not exist)">trilogy</a> involving the return of the <a href="/wiki/Master_(Doctor_Who)" title="Master (Doctor Who)">Master</a>. They were released on DVD under the banner title <i>New Beginnings</i>.
</p>
<table class="wikitable" style="width:100%; margin-right:0;">

<tr>

<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Season_20_.281983.29">Season 20 (1983)</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
To commemorate the twentieth season, the stories in this season involve the return of previous villains. <i><a href="/wiki/Mawdryn_Undead" title="Mawdryn Undead">Mawdryn Undead</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Terminus_(Doctor_Who)" title="Terminus (Doctor Who)">Terminus</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Enlightenment_(Doctor_Who)" title="Enlightenment (Doctor Who)">Enlightenment</a></i> involve the <a href="/wiki/Black_Guardian" title="Black Guardian">Black Guardian</a>'s plot to kill the Doctor; they were released individually on VHS and as a set on DVD as parts of <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Black_Guardian_Trilogy&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Black Guardian Trilogy (page does not exist)">The Black Guardian Trilogy</a></i>. This season was broadcast twice weekly on Tuesday and Wednesday evenings on BBC1.
</p>

<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Season_21_.281984.29">Season 21 (1984)</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
Episodes were broadcast twice weekly on Thursday and Friday evenings, with <i>Resurrection of the Daleks</i> broadcast on two consecutive Wednesday nights.
</p>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Sixth_Doctor">Sixth Doctor</span></h2>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Sixth_Doctor" title="Sixth Doctor">Sixth Doctor</a> was portrayed by <a href="/wiki/Colin_Baker" title="Colin Baker">Colin Baker</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Season_21_.281984.29_continued">Season 21 (1984) continued</span></h3>
<table class="wikitable" style="width:100%; margin-right:0;">

<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Season_22_.281985.29">Season 22 (1985)</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
The series moved back to once-weekly Saturday broadcasts. All episodes were 45 minutes long, though they also exist in 25-minute versions. Although there were now only 13 episodes in the season, the total running time remained approximately the same as in previous seasons since the episodes were almost twice as long.
</p>

<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Season_23_.281986.29">Season 23 (1986)</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
After an 18-month production hiatus, the series returned. Eric Saward was script editor up to part eight, when Nathan-Turner unofficially took over script editing the remainder of the season because of Saward's departure. The whole season is titled as <i>The Trial of a Time Lord</i>, and is split into four segments. The segments are commonly referred to by their working titles<sup id="cite_ref-24" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-24">[13]</a></sup> (listed below) but the season was broadcast as one fourteen-part story and the working titles did not appear on screen. Episode length returned to 25 minutes, but with only fourteen episodes in the season, making the total running time of this season (and subsequent seasons) just over half of the previous seasons, going back to season 7.
</p>
<table class="wikitable" style="width:100%; margin-right:0;">

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Seventh_Doctor">Seventh Doctor</span></h2>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Seventh_Doctor" title="Seventh Doctor">Seventh Doctor</a> was portrayed by <a href="/wiki/Sylvester_McCoy" title="Sylvester McCoy">Sylvester McCoy</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Season_24_.281987.29">Season 24 (1987)</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
<a href="/wiki/Andrew_Cartmel" title="Andrew Cartmel">Andrew Cartmel</a> took over as script editor. This season was moved to a Monday schedule.
</p>

<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Season_26_.281989.29">Season 26 (1989)</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
The final season continued to push the series towards a darker approach, focusing this time more on Ace's personal life as well as The Doctor's past and manipulations. This season set the tone for the <a href="/wiki/Virgin_New_Adventures" title="Virgin New Adventures">Virgin New Adventures</a> novels that followed.
</p>
<table class="wikitable" style="width:100%; margin-right:0;">

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Eighth_Doctor">Eighth Doctor</span></h2>
<p>The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Eighth_Doctor&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Eighth Doctor (page does not exist)">Eighth Doctor</a> was portrayed by <a href="/wiki/Paul_McGann" title="Paul McGann">Paul McGann</a>. The movie is the only television appearance of this Doctor during his tenure. The only production title held by this story was <i>Doctor Who</i>. However, producer <a href="/wiki/Philip_Segal" title="Philip Segal">Philip Segal</a> later suggested <i>Enemy Within</i> as an alternative title. Lacking any other specific name, many fans have adopted this to refer to the movie. Fan groups have also used other informal titles. The DVD release is titled <i>Doctor Who: The Movie</i>.  In 2013, Paul McGann returned for the second television appearance of the Eighth Doctor in the minisode titled, "<a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Night_of_the_Doctor&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Night of the Doctor (page does not exist)">The Night of the Doctor</a>".
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Television_movie_.281996.29">Television movie (1996)</span></h3>
<table class="wikitable" style="width:100%; margin-right:0;">

<tr>

<th scope="col" style="width:20%;"> Episodes
</th>
<th scope="col" style="width:13%;"> Writer

</th></tr>
<tr>
<th scope="row">156
</th>
<td><i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Doctor_Who_(1996_film)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Doctor Who (1996 film) (page does not exist)">Doctor Who</a></i>
</td>
<td>TVM<sup id="cite_ref-TVM_31-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-TVM-31">[lower-greek 12]</a></sup>
</td>
<td>Television movie <small>(89 mins)</small>
</td>
<td><a href="/w/index.php?title=Matthew_Jacobs&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Matthew Jacobs (page does not exist)">Matthew Jacobs</a>
</td>
<td><a href="/wiki/Geoffrey_Sax" title="Geoffrey Sax">Geoffrey Sax</a>
</td>
<td>12 May 1996 (Canada)<br />14 May 1996 (USA)<br />27 May 1996 (UK)
</td></tr></table>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Ninth_Doctor">Ninth Doctor</span></h2>
<p>In 2005, the BBC relaunched <i><a href="/wiki/Doctor_Who" title="Doctor Who">Doctor Who</a></i> after a 16-year absence from episodic television, with <a href="/wiki/Russell_T_Davies" title="Russell T Davies">Russell T Davies</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Julie_Gardner&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Julie Gardner (page does not exist)">Julie Gardner</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mal_Young" title="Mal Young">Mal Young</a> as executive producers, <a href="/wiki/Phil_Collinson" title="Phil Collinson">Phil Collinson</a> as producer, and <a href="/wiki/Christopher_Eccleston" title="Christopher Eccleston">Christopher Eccleston</a> taking the lead role of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ninth_Doctor&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ninth Doctor (page does not exist)">Ninth Doctor</a>.
</p><p>The revival adheres to the original continuity. The new series is formatted to a <a href="/wiki/16:9" title="16:9">16:9</a> <a href="/wiki/Widescreen" title="Widescreen">widescreen</a> display ratio, and a standard episode length of 45 minutes. For the first time since the 1965/66 season each episode has an individual title, although most stories do not span more than one episode. The show also returned to its traditional Saturday evening slot.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Series_1_.282005.29">Series 1 (2005)</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
The 2005 series constitutes a loose story arc, dealing with the consequences of the <a href="/wiki/Time_War_(Doctor_Who)" title="Time War (Doctor Who)">Time War</a> and the mysterious <a href="/wiki/Bad_Wolf_references_in_Doctor_Who" title="Bad Wolf references in Doctor Who" class="mw-redirect">Bad Wolf</a>.
</p>
<table class="wikitable" style="width:100%; margin-right:0;">

<tr>
<th scope="col" style="width:4%;"> No
</th>
<th scope="col" style="width:27%;"> Title
</th>
<th scope="col" style="width:5%;"> Code
</th>
<th scope="col" style="width:20%;"> Episodes
</th>
<th scope="col" style="width:13%;"> Writer
</th>
<th scope="col" style="width:15%;"> Director
</th>
<th scope="col" style="width:16%;"> Original airdate
</th></tr>
<tr>
<th scope="row">157
</th>
<td>"<a href="/wiki/Rose_(Doctor_Who)" title="Rose (Doctor Who)">Rose</a>"
</td>
<td>1.1
</td>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Tenth_Doctor">Tenth Doctor</span></h2>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Tenth_Doctor" title="Tenth Doctor">Tenth Doctor</a> was portrayed by <a href="/wiki/David_Tennant" title="David Tennant">David Tennant</a>, who was cast before the first series aired.<sup id="cite_ref-32" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-32">[19]</a></sup> Mal Young vacated his position as executive producer when he departed the BBC after Series 1. He was not replaced in that capacity.
</p>

<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Series_2_.282006.29">Series 2 (2006)</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Back-story&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Back-story (page does not exist)">back-story</a> for the spin-off series <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Torchwood&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Torchwood (page does not exist)">Torchwood</a></i> is "seeded" in various episodes in the 2006 series. Each episode also has an accompanying online <a href="/w/index.php?title=TARDISODE&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="TARDISODE (page does not exist)">TARDISODE</a>.
</p>

<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Series_3_.282007.29">Series 3 (2007)</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
This series introduces <a href="/w/index.php?title=Martha_Jones&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Martha Jones (page does not exist)">Martha Jones</a> and deals with the <a href="/wiki/Face_of_Boe" title="Face of Boe">Face of Boe</a>'s final message, the mysterious <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mr._Saxon&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mr. Saxon (page does not exist)">Mr. Saxon</a>, and the Doctor dealing with the loss of <a href="/wiki/Rose_Tyler" title="Rose Tyler">Rose Tyler</a>. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Susie_Liggat&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Susie Liggat (page does not exist)">Susie Liggat</a> was the producer for "Human Nature" and "The Family of Blood", with Phil Collinson credited as executive producer for those episodes.
</p>

<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Specials_.282007.29">Specials (2007)</span></h3>
<table class="wikitable" style="width:100%; margin-right:0;">

<tr>
<th scope="col" style="width:4%;"> No
</th>
<th scope="col" style="width:27%;"> Title
</th>
<th scope="col" style="width:5%;"> Code
</th>
<th scope="col" style="width:20%;"> Episodes
</th>
<th scope="col" style="width:13%;"> Writer
</th>
<th scope="col" style="width:15%;"> Director
</th>
<th scope="col" style="width:16%;"> Original airdate
</th></tr>
<tr>
<th scope="row">—

<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Series_4_.282008.29">Series 4 (2008)</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
This series explores the coincidences binding the Doctor and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Donna_Noble&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Donna Noble (page does not exist)">Donna</a> together. Susie Liggat was the producer for "Planet of the Ood", "The Sontaran Stratagem", "The Poison Sky", "The Unicorn and the Wasp" and "Turn Left", with Phil Collinson credited as executive producer for those episodes. Phil Collinson left the position of producer at the end of the series.
</p>
<table class="wikitable" style="width:100%; margin-right:0;">

<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Specials_.282008.E2.80.9310.29_.7B.7B.23invoke:anchor.7Cmain.7D.7D">Specials (2008–10) {{#invoke:anchor|main}}</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
From "Planet of the Dead", episodes were filmed in <a href="/w/index.php?title=High-definition_television&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="High-definition television (page does not exist)">HD</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-36" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-36">[22]</a></sup> Susie Liggat produced "The Next Doctor", while <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nikki_Wilson&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nikki Wilson (page does not exist)">Nikki Wilson</a> produced "The Waters of Mars" and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Tracie_Simpson&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tracie Simpson (page does not exist)">Tracie Simpson</a> produced "Planet of the Dead" and <i>The End of Time</i>. For practical reasons, these specials continued to use Series 4 production codes.
</p>
<table class="wikitable" style="width:100%; margin-right:0;">

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Eleventh_Doctor">Eleventh Doctor</span></h2>
<p>The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Eleventh_Doctor&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Eleventh Doctor (page does not exist)">Eleventh Doctor</a> was portrayed by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Matt_Smith_(actor)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Matt Smith (actor) (page does not exist)">Matt Smith</a>. Steven Moffat took over as head writer and executive producer after Russell T Davies stepped down. Julie Gardner also stepped down as executive producer and was replaced by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Piers_Wenger&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Piers Wenger (page does not exist)">Piers Wenger</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Beth_Willis_(producer)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Beth Willis (producer) (page does not exist)">Beth Willis</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Series_5_.282010.29">Series 5 (2010)</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Tracie_Simpson&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tracie Simpson (page does not exist)">Tracie Simpson</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Peter_Bennett_(producer)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Peter Bennett (producer) (page does not exist)">Peter Bennett</a> shared producer duties for this series only, with Patrick Schweitzer co-producing with Simpson for "The Vampires of Venice" and "Vincent and the Doctor".
</p>
<table class="wikitable" style="width:100%; margin-right:0;">

<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Specials_.282010.E2.80.9311.29_.7B.7B.23invoke:anchor.7Cmain.7D.7D">Specials (2010–11) {{#invoke:anchor|main}}</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Sanne_Wohlenberg&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sanne Wohlenberg (page does not exist)">Sanne Wohlenberg</a> produced "A Christmas Carol".
</p>

<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Series_6_.282011.29">Series 6 (2011)</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
The original transmission of series 6 was split into two parts, with the first seven episodes airing April to June 2011 and the final six from late August to October 2011. Sanne Wohlenberg continued as producer for the first block of filming, consisting of "The Doctor's Wife" and "Night Terrors". Marcus Wilson then took over as series producer, with Denise Paul producing "Closing Time".
</p>
<table class="wikitable" style="width:100%; margin-right:0;">

<tr>
<th scope="col" style="width:4%;"> No
</th>
<th scope="col" style="width:27%;"> Title
</th>
<th scope="col" style="width:5%;"> Code
</th>
<th scope="col" style="width:20%;"> Episodes
</th>

<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Specials_.282011.E2.80.9312.29_.7B.7B.23invoke:anchor.7Cmain.7D.7D">Specials (2011–12) {{#invoke:anchor|main}}</span></h3>
<p>The Christmas special was executive produced by Moffat, Wenger and Caroline Skinner.<sup id="cite_ref-38" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-38">[23]</a></sup> Beth Willis left the BBC and stepped down as executive producer after series 6<sup id="cite_ref-39" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-39">[24]</a></sup> and Wenger also departed following the Christmas special, leaving Moffat and Skinner as executive producers for series 7.<sup id="cite_ref-40" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-40">[25]</a></sup>
</p>
<table class="wikitable" style="width:100%; margin-right:0;">

<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Series_7_Part_1_.282012.29_.7B.7B.23invoke:anchor.7Cmain.7D.7D">Series 7 Part 1 (2012) {{#invoke:anchor|main}}</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
Series 7 started with five episodes in late 2012, followed by a Christmas special and eight episodes in 2013.

<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Series_7_Part_2_.282013.29">Series 7 Part 2 (2013)</span></h3>
<p>Denise Paul produced "The Bells of Saint John", "The Rings of Akhaten", "Nightmare in Silver" and "The Name of the Doctor" with Marcus Wilson credited as series producer on those episodes.

<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Specials_.282013.29">Specials (2013)</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
Following Caroline Skinner's departure, BBC Wales' Head of Drama, Faith Penhale, served as Executive Producer with Moffat for the 50th anniversary special;<sup id="cite_ref-EP13_41-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EP13-41">[26]</a></sup> Brian Minchin, previously a script editor in series 5, took over the role thereafter.<sup id="cite_ref-42" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-42">[27]</a></sup>
</p>
<table class="wikitable" style="width:100%; margin-right:0;">

</th></tr>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Twelfth_Doctor">Twelfth Doctor</span></h2>
<p>On 1 June 2013, Matt Smith announced he would be stepping down from the role of the Doctor. In the live television event <i>Doctor Who Live: The Next Doctor</i> on 4 August 2013, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Peter_Capaldi&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Peter Capaldi (page does not exist)">Peter Capaldi</a> was presented as the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Twelfth_Doctor&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Twelfth Doctor (page does not exist)">Twelfth Doctor</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Series_8_.282014.29">Series 8 (2014)</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
It is planned that the eighth series will contain 13 episodes to be broadcast in Q3-Q4 2014, not  split into two parts but transmitted on consecutive weeks.<sup id="cite_ref-43" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-43">[28]</a></sup> Starring Peter Capaldi as the Doctor and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jenna_Coleman&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jenna Coleman (page does not exist)">Jenna Coleman</a> as Clara Oswald, filming is due to start in January 2014.<sup id="cite_ref-series_eight-2_44-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-series_eight-2-44">[29]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ben_Wheatley&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ben Wheatley (page does not exist)">Ben Wheatley</a> will direct Capaldi's first two episodes,<sup id="cite_ref-45" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-45">[30]</a></sup> Paul Murphy will direct episodes three and six.<sup id="cite_ref-46" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-46">[31]</a></sup> and Douglas Mackinnon will direct two episodes.<sup id="cite_ref-47" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-47">[32]</a></sup> It was announced that Marcus Wilson would be replaced as producer by Nikki Wilson and Peter Bennett.<sup id="cite_ref-series9_10-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-series9-10">[9]</a></sup>
</p>
<table class="wikitable" style="width:100%; margin-right:0;">

</td></tr></table>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Other_stories">Other stories</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Television_broadcasts">Television broadcasts</span></h3>
<p>There have also been several special <i>Doctor Who</i> episodes and serials that are produced by the BBC. They usually consist of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Parody&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Parody (page does not exist)">spoofs</a> and <a href="/wiki/Fictional_crossover" title="Fictional crossover">crossovers</a> with other TV shows, and stories produced for special occasions.
</p>
<table class="wikitable" style="width:100%; margin-right:0;">

</td></tr></table>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Radio_broadcasts">Radio broadcasts</span></h3>
<p>There have been many <i>Doctor Who</i> radio broadcasts over the years. In addition to a small number of in-house BBC productions, a larger number of radio plays produced by <a href="/wiki/Big_Finish_Productions" title="Big Finish Productions">Big Finish</a> began to be broadcast on <a href="/w/index.php?title=BBC_Radio_7&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="BBC Radio 7 (page does not exist)">BBC Radio 7</a> from 2005, featuring the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Eighth_Doctor&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Eighth Doctor (page does not exist)">Eighth Doctor</a> (again played by <a href="/wiki/Paul_McGann" title="Paul McGann">Paul McGann</a>) with mainstay companions <a href="/wiki/Charley_Pollard" title="Charley Pollard">Charley Pollard</a> and later <a href="/w/index.php?title=Lucie_Miller&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Lucie Miller (page does not exist)">Lucie Miller</a>. Initially, these were broadcasts of Big Finish productions that had already been released on CD. However, the series that began with <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Blood_of_the_Daleks&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Blood of the Daleks (page does not exist)">Blood of the Daleks</a></i> and concluded with <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Human_Resources_(Doctor_Who_audio)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Human Resources (Doctor Who audio) (page does not exist)">Human Resources</a></i> was specially commissioned by the BBC from Big Finish for broadcast prior to the CD release. Many more of these were released on CD than were broadcast on the radio; only those plays broadcast by the BBC are listed here. See the <a href="/wiki/List_of_Doctor_Who_audio_releases" title="List of Doctor Who audio releases">list of Doctor Who audio releases</a> as a starting point for other audio plays and audio books, notably the <a href="/wiki/List_of_Doctor_Who_audio_plays_by_Big_Finish" title="List of Doctor Who audio plays by Big Finish">list of Doctor Who audio plays by Big Finish</a> which includes considerably more plays than were broadcast.
</p>
<table class="wikitable" style="width:100%; margin-right:0;">

<p>The following are all <a href="/w/index.php?title=Eighth_Doctor&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Eighth Doctor (page does not exist)">Eighth Doctor</a> dramas produced by <a href="/wiki/Big_Finish_Productions" title="Big Finish Productions">Big Finish</a> and broadcast on <a href="/w/index.php?title=BBC_Radio_7&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="BBC Radio 7 (page does not exist)">BBC Radio 7</a>.
</p>

<p>In 2011, <a href="/wiki/BBC_Radio_4_Extra" title="BBC Radio 4 Extra">BBC Radio 4 Extra</a> began a series of <a href="/wiki/Fifth_Doctor" title="Fifth Doctor">Fifth Doctor</a> dramas produced by <a href="/wiki/Big_Finish_Productions" title="Big Finish Productions">Big Finish</a>.
</p>

<td><i><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Cradle_of_the_Snake&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Cradle of the Snake (page does not exist)">The Cradle of the Snake</a></i>

<p>December 2011 saw the broadcast of the <a href="/wiki/Fourth_Doctor" title="Fourth Doctor">Fourth Doctor</a> audio <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Hornets%27_Nest_(Doctor_Who)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hornets' Nest (Doctor Who) (page does not exist)">Hornets' Nest</a></i> on  <a href="/wiki/BBC_Radio_4_Extra" title="BBC Radio 4 Extra">BBC Radio 4 Extra</a>.
</p>
<table class="wikitable" style="width:100%; margin-right:0;">

<p>In 2012, <a href="/wiki/BBC_Radio_4_Extra" title="BBC Radio 4 Extra">BBC Radio 4 Extra</a> began a series of <a href="/wiki/Seventh_Doctor" title="Seventh Doctor">Seventh Doctor</a> dramas produced by <a href="/wiki/Big_Finish_Productions" title="Big Finish Productions">Big Finish</a>.
</p>

</td></tr></table>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Audiobook_readings">Audiobook readings</span></h4>
<p><a href="/wiki/BBC_Radio_4_Extra" title="BBC Radio 4 Extra">BBC Radio 4 Extra</a> has aired some of <a href="/w/index.php?title=BBC_Audio&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="BBC Audio (page does not exist)">BBC Audio</a>'s <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_Doctor_Who_audiobooks&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of Doctor Who audiobooks (page does not exist)">audiobook readings</a> of <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_Doctor_Who_novelisations&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of Doctor Who novelisations (page does not exist)">Classic Series novelisations</a>, all read by <a href="/wiki/Tom_Baker" title="Tom Baker">Tom Baker</a>.
</p>
<table class="wikitable" style="width:100%; margin-right:0;">

<tr>

<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="50th_Anniversary">50th Anniversary</span></h4>
<p>In 2013, <a href="/wiki/BBC_Radio_4_Extra" title="BBC Radio 4 Extra">BBC Radio 4 Extra</a> broadcast 8 audio adventures and talking books from both Big Finish and Audio Go under the title of Doctor Who at 50.
</p>
<table class="wikitable" style="width:100%; margin-right:0;">

<tr>
<th scope="col" style="width:30%;"> Title
</th>
<th scope="col" style="width:20%;"> Episodes
</th>
<th scope="col" style="width:15%;"> Writer
</th>
<th scope="col" style="width:15%;"> Reader / Starring
</th>
<th scope="col" style="width:20%;"> Original airdates
</th></tr>
<tr>

<td><a href="/wiki/David_Whitaker_(screenwriter)" title="David Whitaker (screenwriter)">David Whitaker</a>

</td>

<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Webcasts">Webcasts</span></h3>
<table class="wikitable" style="width:100%; margin-right:0;">

<tr>
<th scope="col" style="width:30%;"> Title
</th>
<th scope="col" style="width:20%;"> Episodes
</th>
<th scope="col" style="width:15%;"> Writer
</th>
<th scope="col" style="width:15%;"> Director
</th>
<th scope="col" style="width:20%;"> Original airdate
</th></tr>
<tr>
<td><i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Death_Comes_to_Time&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Death Comes to Time (page does not exist)">Death Comes to Time</a></i>
</td>
<td>13 parts, 140 minutes in total
</td>
<td>Colin Meek
</td>
<td>Dan Freedman
</td>
<td>13 July 2001 (pilot)<br />14 February – 3 May 2002 (regular)
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td style="background:#fff;" colspan="5">An illustrated audio <a href="/wiki/Webcast" title="Webcast">webcast</a> for <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bbc.co.uk&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bbc.co.uk (page does not exist)">BBCi</a> featuring the Seventh Doctor.
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><i><a href="/wiki/Real_Time_(Doctor_Who)" title="Real Time (Doctor Who)">Real Time</a></i>
</td>
<td>6 parts, 12 minutes each
</td>
<td><a href="/wiki/Gary_Russell" title="Gary Russell">Gary Russell</a>
</td>
<td>Gary Russell
</td>
<td>2 August – 6 September 2002
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td style="background:#fff;" colspan="5">An illustrated audio webcast for BBCi featuring the Sixth Doctor.
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><i><a href="/wiki/Shada" title="Shada">Shada</a></i>
</td>
<td>6 parts, 25 minutes each
</td>
<td>Douglas Adams
</td>
<td><a href="/w/index.php?title=Nicholas_Pegg&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nicholas Pegg (page does not exist)">Nicholas Pegg</a>
</td>
<td>2 May – 6 June 2003
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td style="background:#fff;" colspan="5">An illustrated audio webcast for BBCi featuring the Eighth Doctor in a remake of the unfinished Fourth Doctor serial.
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><i><a href="/wiki/Scream_of_the_Shalka" title="Scream of the Shalka">Scream of the Shalka</a></i>
</td>
<td>6 parts, 15 minutes each
</td>
<td>Paul Cornell
</td>
<td><a href="/w/index.php?title=Wilson_Milam&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Wilson Milam (page does not exist)">Wilson Milam</a>
</td>
<td>13 November – 18 December 2003
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td style="background:#fff;" colspan="5">Animated webcast for BBCi featuring an alternative version of the Ninth Doctor known as the <a href="/wiki/Shalka_Doctor" title="Shalka Doctor">Shalka Doctor</a>, played by <a href="/wiki/Richard_E._Grant" title="Richard E. Grant">Richard E. Grant</a>.
</td></tr></table>
<p><i>Death Comes to Time</i> was released on CD by the BBC, and later re-released as an MP3 CD featuring the original illustrations. <i>Real Time</i> and <i>Shada</i> were released on CD by <a href="/wiki/Big_Finish_Productions" title="Big Finish Productions">Big Finish</a>. The webcast for Shada was released on DVD on 7 January 2013 as part of 'The Legacy Collection' and is only viewable on a PC or MAC. <i>Scream of the Shalka</i> was released in novel form in the <i><a href="/wiki/Past_Doctor_Adventures" title="Past Doctor Adventures">Past Doctor Adventures</a></i> series. While it has been classified for DVD release by the <a href="/w/index.php?title=British_Board_of_Film_Classification&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="British Board of Film Classification (page does not exist)">BBFC</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-83" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-83">[68]</a></sup> a planned release was postponed due to the programme's return to television. It was later released on 16 September 2013.<sup id="cite_ref-84" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-84">[69]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Video_games">Video games</span></h3>
<p>In 1983 <a href="/w/index.php?title=Doctor_Who:_The_First_Adventure&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Doctor Who: The First Adventure (page does not exist)">Doctor Who: The First Adventure</a> was released for the <a href="/w/index.php?title=BBC_Micro&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="BBC Micro (page does not exist)">BBC Micro</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-85" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-85">[70]</a></sup> followed by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Doctor_Who_and_the_Warlord&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Doctor Who and the Warlord (page does not exist)">Doctor Who and the Warlord</a> in 1985<sup id="cite_ref-86" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-86">[71]</a></sup> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Doctor_Who_and_the_Mines_of_Terror&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Doctor Who and the Mines of Terror (page does not exist)">Doctor Who and the Mines of Terror</a> also in 1985.<sup id="cite_ref-87" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-87">[72]</a></sup> Later several other games were released.
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="The_Adventure_Games"><i>The Adventure Games</i></span></h4>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
On 7 April 2010, the BBC announced that the fifth series would be supplemented with four "interactive episodes",<sup id="cite_ref-AdventureGamesAnnounced_88-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-AdventureGamesAnnounced-88">[73]</a></sup> released online for free in the UK. They are described as "part of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Whoniverse&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Whoniverse (page does not exist)"><i>Doctor Who</i> universe</a>", and will "go on to define the look and feel of future TV episodes." Executively produced by Moffat, Wenger and Willis with Anwen Aspden and <a href="/wiki/Charles_Cecil" title="Charles Cecil">Charles Cecil</a>, the games are developed by <a href="/wiki/Sumo_Digital" title="Sumo Digital">Sumo Digital</a> and written by Phil Ford and James Moran. Matt Smith and Karen Gillan provide full voiceovers for the digitised Doctor and Amy, both of whom are playable characters. Each episode offers around two hours of gameplay.<sup id="cite_ref-AdventureGamesAnnounced_88-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-AdventureGamesAnnounced-88">[73]</a></sup> The Adventure Games were recommissioned by the BBC for a second series in 2011,<sup id="cite_ref-89" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-89">[74]</a></sup> but after the release of The Gunpowder Plot, they were cancelled so the BBC could focus more on console games such as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Doctor_Who:_The_Eternity_Clock&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Doctor Who: The Eternity Clock (page does not exist)">Doctor Who: The Eternity Clock</a>.
</p>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Sources">Sources</span></h2>

</p>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="External_links">External links</span></h2>
<ul>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.bbc.co.uk/doctorwho/classic/episodeguide/">BBC Classic Series Episode Guide</a>
</li>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b006q2x0/episodes/guide">BBC Episode Guide (Classic and New Series)</a>
</li>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.drwhoguide.com/">Doctor Who Reference Guide</a> – detailed descriptions of all televised episodes, plus spin-off audio, video, and literary works.
</li>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0056751/"><i>Doctor Who (1963–1989)</i> </a> at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Internet_Movie_Database&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Internet Movie Database (page does not exist)">Internet Movie Database</a>
</li>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0116118/"><i>Doctor Who (1996)</i> </a> at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Internet_Movie_Database&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Internet Movie Database (page does not exist)">Internet Movie Database</a>
</li>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0436992/"><i>Doctor Who (2005–)</i> </a> at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Internet_Movie_Database&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Internet Movie Database (page does not exist)">Internet Movie Database</a>
</li>
</ul>
